document.text: The April Career Assembly was held in the Appomattox County High School Auditorium April 16, 1975. This months program centered on the proper techniques for a job application and job interviews. Mrs. Polly DePew Guidance Counselor and advisor for the Career Assembly opened our monthly meeting by explaining the program and introducing the guests. Students from ACHS also prepared a skit showing the proper and improper way of applying for a job interview. Students participating were Lynn Allen Smith a member of the Distributive Education Clubs of America who was Personnel Manager. Cindy Guill and Julie Moore were both secretaries applying at the job interview and Gay Honeycutt was receptionist for the skit. Also as our guest for the assembly we had Mr. Roger Redman, , Personnel Director at Thomasville Furniture Industries, and Mr. Buddy Carson, Personnel Director at Appomattox Garment Company. Both men discussed the qualities looked for in an individual when applying for a job and also job attitudes and opportunities. The April Career Assembly was very successful and informative. document.text: In response to a petition filed by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union of the American Federation of Labor, a secret ballot! election will be conducted at the Appomattox Garment Company s finishing plant October 31. , The election will be conducted by the National Relations Board. Garment workers at the Appomattox plant will have the option of voting to allow the ILGW set up a local union at the industry, or of maintaining an open shop. .. . , The is the second time in the 30 year history of Appomattox Garment Company that the union has attempted to introduce a local chapter. IN 1954 the National Labor Relations Board cancelled an election, but the union called for a strike which lasted more than a year at the plant here and the Lynn plant in Lynchburg. _ , __ , , Since that time Appomattox Garment has expanded to 14 plants,, 10 in Virginia and four in neighboring states. A combined yearly payroll of more than two and a half million dollars is realized by employees of the sewing plant and the finishing plant, both quartered in Appomattox County. _ Six union organizer from Baltimore, Md. have been in Appomattox County for more than eight months in an effort to sway the 320 employees in favor of a closed shop operation. , . Company president Fred Lawson says, I am grateful for the cooperation and patience our employees have displayed during this long campaign. Despite the confusion and pressure brought about by the organizing drive, we are appreciative of the good attitude most of the employees have shown toward the company, and toward their work. Perhaps with the issue settled on October 31, we can return all our efforts to producing top quality childrens garments in Appomattox.

document.text: During the month of October agreements were signed by Robert Englander, president of Appomattox Garment Company and Irwin G. Freydberg, president of G. H.  E. Freydberg which assures the Appo mattox Garment Company family of being sole producers of Patricia Ann dresses for the next ten years. Up until these agreements were made, the contracts to make Patricia Ann dresses were of short duration. Now there is a relationship that as sures continual work from Freyd berg through 1964. It was possible to arrange for this new security only because of the excellent record our employees have made with re spect to quality of production, on- time deliveries, and in general the development of satisfied customers, said Fred Lawson, company execu tive vice president. In order to accomplish these ar rangements, a great deal of legal and technical work had to be done. A new company was formed which is another addition to the Appomattox group. Appomattox Garment Com pany and Lynn Manufacturing Com pany have now been joined by the Factory Realty Corporation. As Lynn is the division of the business that does the cutting, and as the Appomattox branch is the company that does the manufacturing, Fac tory Realty is now the branch of the group that owns the buildings in Appomattox, and the machinery both in Appomattox and Lynchburg. document.text: The following review of county happenings is by no means com plete, and yet, even a brief re port of activities of business men, organizations, and individ uals during 1962 may give many readers cause for encourage ment and pride in Appomattox County as its citizens begin work on a New Year. Forestry, one of the most im portant segments in county econ omy. received a boost by the formation of a Forestry Club in late November. Through pro fessional advice and stimulus of prizes, plus sale profits, county tree growers are being encourag ed to harvest trees wisely, and to replant county acreage. Needy cancer patients can now draw upon funds not available in 1962 because of the formation of a county Cancer Council. Colonial Pipeline bought a right - of - way to many acres of county land, preparing for a 1600 mile pipeline to carry oil products from Texas to New York. Memorial Methodist Church erected a new building Liberty Baptist Church did extensive re novation, and several other con gregations, Including St. Anns Episcopal, Appomattox Court House Presbyterian, and Hebron Baptist Church made additions and improvements to their church buildings. New, private homes appeared by the dozen during the year. The Bank of Appomattox open ed their first branch bank, and Pamplin began plans for a bank to service their community.
